moves.1. d4: I have been playing D4 for four months now after 20+ years of E4 I don't know why I didn't try it earlier
moves.1... Nf6: A typical response (infact I play this myself)
moves.4. c3 Nc6 5. e3 Qb6: I debated offering the queen exchange here
moves.6. Qc1 Bf5 7. Nbd2 e6 8. Nh4: I decide that I want the d3 square for my bishop
moves.9... Be7 10. h3: Now to chase the bishop and give my black squared bishop an escape square
moves.10... Bh5 11. O-O cxd4: I was surprised by this but it does open the c file for black
moves.12. exd4 O-O: I suspect black is planninng rook to c8. I need to bring my knight back to a more active square
moves.13. Nhf3 Rac8: Sure enough the Rook comes accross
moves.15. Nxf3 Rfe8 16. Re1: All is even at the moment but white has a little more pressure
moves.16... h6 17. a4: Time to switch focus to the queenside
moves.17... Qd8 18. Qd1 a6 19. Ne5 Nxe5 20. Bx: I don't want to exchange just yet
moves.25... Nh5: I will deprive the knight of squares
moves.28... Kg8 29. Ra3 Nd7 30. Raa1 e5 31. dx: Now we are moving towards an end game which I believe will favour white because of the isolated Queens pawn
moves.39... Qe8 40. Kf2 Kg8 41. Qd3 Qc6 42. Rd: It is a matter of time, blacks best hope is to avoid the exchange of queens and try to steal a pawn back
moves.47... Ke7 48. Qe5+: The queens must come off and now it is a formality
Black resigns. This was a hard fought game and I was very relieved to get the point.
